stocks.title: What Are Stocks?
stocks.description: Understanding the basics of stock ownership and equity

content.heading: Stock Basics
content.text: A stock represents ownership in a company. When you buy a stock, you become a shareholder and own a small piece of that company.
content.example: If you buy 10 shares of Apple at $150 each, you own $1,500 worth of Apple stock.

stocks.title: How the Stock Market Works
stocks.description: Learn about exchanges, trading, and market mechanics

content.heading: Stock Exchanges
content.text: Stock exchanges like NYSE and NASDAQ are marketplaces where buyers and sellers trade stocks.
content.example: The NYSE is the world's largest stock exchange with thousands of companies listed.

stocks.title: Reading Stock Charts
stocks.description: Master the basics of technical analysis

content.heading: Price Charts
content.text: Stock charts display price movements over time. Candlestick charts reveal opening, closing, high, and low prices.
content.example: A green candlestick means closing price was higher than opening (bullish).

content.heading: Diversification
content.text: Spread investments across different sectors and asset types to reduce risk.
content.example: Balance tech stocks with healthcare, consumer goods, and financial stocks.

content.heading: What is Forex?
content.text: Forex is the global marketplace for trading currencies. Over $6 trillion traded daily, 24/5 operation.
content.example: When you exchange dollars for euros while traveling, you're participating in forex.

content.heading: Reading Currency Pairs
content.text: Currency pairs show two currencies: base currency (first) and quote currency (second).
content.example: EUR/USD = 1.10 means 1 euro equals 1.10 US dollars.

content.heading: Day Trading
content.text: Open and close positions within the same day, avoiding overnight risk.
content.example: Make 5-10 trades during London session, capturing small profits.

content.heading: Leverage and Margin
content.text: Forex uses leverage, amplifying both profits and losses. Use cautiously.

content.heading: Digital Currency Basics
content.text: Cryptocurrency is digital money existing only electronically, operating on decentralized networks.
content.example: Bitcoin, created in 2009, was the first cryptocurrency.

content.heading: What is Blockchain?
content.text: A distributed ledger - a database shared across many computers. Once added, blocks cannot be altered.
content.example: Like a shared Google Doc everyone can read, but no one can erase.

content.heading: Bitcoin (BTC)
content.text: The first and most valuable cryptocurrency with a capped supply of 21 million coins.

content.heading: Types of Wallets
content.text: Hot wallets are online (convenient but less secure). Cold wallets are offline (more secure).
content.example: Keep small amounts in hot wallet, store long-term holdings in cold wallet.
